title: 108_hr1874
content: The Act is titled the "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" and includes a demonstration project to clarify the definition of homebound. The Secretary will conduct a demonstration project under which medicare beneficiaries with chronic conditions are deemed homebound for receiving home health services. Medicare beneficiaries must meet specific criteria to be eligible for this designation, including having a permanent and severe condition, requiring assistance with daily living activities, needing home health services to improve functionality, and requiring assistance to leave the home. The Secretary will collect data on a demonstration project providing home health services to Medicare beneficiaries, focusing on quality of care, patient outcomes, and any additional costs to the program. Reports will be submitted to Congress within one year of implementation, with waiver authority granted to conduct demonstration projects. The Secretary has the authority to waive compliance with certain requirements under the Social Security Act for demonstration projects. This section does not waive any penalties or remedies available to the Secretary for prohibited acts. Funds from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Insurance Trust Fund can be appropriated for the demonstration project. Definitions include terms like "Medicare beneficiary." The Secretary can use necessary funds for the demonstration project. Definitions include "Medicare beneficiary," "home health services," and "activities of daily living." The Secretary refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Clarification of the definition of homebound for determining eligibility for home health services under the Medicare program. The Social Security Act is amended to allow individuals with permanent severe conditions requiring assistance with daily activities to qualify as 'confined to home' for Medicare home health services. The term 'activities of daily living' includes eating, toileting, transferring, bathing, and dressing. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report to Congress by December 1, 2006, analyzing the impact of a demonstration project on home health services under Medicare. The project will end on January 1, 2007, unless data shows adverse effects on home health services or unreasonable cost increases under Medicare. The Secretary must report to Congress by December 1, 2006, on the impact of a demonstration project on home health services under Medicare. If the project adversely affects services or causes unreasonable cost increases, specific data and recommendations must be included in the report. The Act requires the Secretary to report to Congress on the impact of a demonstration project on home health services under Medicare, including recommendations to exempt severely disabled homebound beneficiaries from restrictions on absences. Technical amendments are made to sections of the Social Security Act.
